entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 1
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1 (#1)

Nmap output:

Enumeration of Samba:

The service is running with the root privileges and we can use exploit in Metasploit to obtain root account:

Because Apache is vulnerable, there is another solution. Nikto reports something interesting:

Web server signature:

In exploitdb we find:

Because the exploit is pretty old, we need to update it with these steps:

Finally we run the exploit and cat /etc/shadow with the root privileges.

entry.title: pWnOS: 1.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 1.0

Nmap output:

After a while of browsing the web page, we found trivial LFI vulnerability:

We can find a lot of information querying the samba service too:

There are a few enumeration modules in metasploit:

The webmin is vulnerable and the exploit in metasploit:

Basically the exploitation could be performed on command line to disclose arbitrary file, for example:

Using john on /etc/shadow, we obtain credentials of user vmware for successful login to the system:

The box could be rooted using standard vmsplice exploit.

However, there is another way to get user account. The script dowkd.pl ensures us that the OpenSSL is vulnerable (CVE-2008-0166).

We download and unpack already generated RSA keys from offensive-security repository:

Because usage of weak private keys could be blacklisted on our server, we use the following instructions to enable them.

Basically adding this directive to our ssh_config file should be sufficient:

In exploitdb, we use python script to try every possible private key:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S2.100
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S2.100

Nmap output:

We found out that there is another IP address on the same network:

Enumerating SMTP users, we get:

We used CEWL to create wordlist (userlist.txt) to reveal another user accounts. Before we use this command, it’s good to check if the disk is not full for proper SMTP functionality.

Again, this could be automatized using smtp-user-enum script:

Dirb found the following URLs:

We download the private key of pirrip user and log in:

The root accound can be obtained using exploit from Kali:

There is another way to get root account. At first we find out the password for pirrip user:

Finally, in /root/.save we obtain the following data:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.110
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.110

Nmap output:

FTP anonymous login is allowed:

We have found a few files, but nothing particularly interesting:

More about cygwin format here.

In /etc directory, there is a core file which contains password hashes:

After adjusting:

We log in as user bbanter and obtain root permissions:

Lastly, we check the backup file and decrypt CSV:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.100
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.100

The output from nmap:

We connect to the web site and save the staff names to the file:

Using this script namelist.py we generate the potential login names:

In this case, the better way should be to use SMTP enumeration:

We use hydra to perform brute-force attack via imap service:

After login as bbanter, we download the /etc/passwd file to create more accurate wordlist:

We found no working exploit using Linux_Exploit_Suggester.

User aadams is in the wheel group:

Checking sudo -l reveals how to get root hash:

Using John, we cracked these hashes:

We find salary_dec2003.csv.enc in FTP directory and because there is suspicous line in /etc/passwd (DO NOT CHANGE PASSWORD - WILL BREAK FTP ENCRYPTION), we know that the password for this file could be the same as for root.

For this purpose, we wroted the following script:

In a few gibberish files we read csv/salary_dec2003.csv.aes-128-cbc-decrypted:
